Translit: 1

Transliteration and translation by Claude Opus 4.5, December 2025

Right-Hand Column: Internal Affairs (Umur-i Dahiliye)

Line 1
Script: ❁ امور داخلیه ❁
Translit: Umûr-ı Dâḫiliye
Literal: Affairs of Internal [Matters]
Modern: Internal Affairs

Line 2
Script: خصوص آتی شوکتلو قدرتلو مهابتلو پادشاه اسلام پناه افندیمز حضرتلرینك
Translit: Ḫuṣûṣ-ı âtî şevketlü ḳudretlü mehâbetlü pâdişâh-ı İslâm-penâh efendimiz ḥażretleriniñ
Literal: The following matter: Of His Majesty our master, the Islam-protecting Padishah possessing majesty, power, and grandeur
Modern: The following matter concerns His Majesty our Padishah, Protector of Islam, possessed of majesty, power, and grandeur,

Line 3
Script: برایا پرورلك نیت خیریه سیله چند ماه مقدم وقوعبولان اقدکز بوغازینه و ادرنه یه
Translit: berâyâ-perverlik niyet-i ḫayriyesiyle çend mâh muḳaddem vuḳû'-bulan Aḳdeñiz boġazına ve Edirne'ye
Literal: With the benevolent intention of subject-cherishing, [regarding that which] occurred several months ago, to the Aegean strait and to Edirne
Modern: Whose benevolent intention to care for his subjects [led to] the journey that took place several months ago to the Dardanelles and Edirne.

Line 4
Script: عزیمت همایونلرینی ناطق مادۀ مخصوصه در که تبرکا بونکله ابتدا اولنمشدر
Translit: 'azîmet-i hümâyûnlarını nâṭıḳ mâdde-i maḫṣûṣadır ki teberrüken bunuñla ibtidâ olunmuşdur
Literal: It is the special article speaking of their imperial journey, with which, for blessing, a beginning has been made
Modern: This is the special article describing His Imperial journey, with which [this newspaper] has been auspiciously inaugurated.

Line 5
Script: [blank line]
Translit: —
Literal: —
Modern: —

Line 6
Script: شهریار محاسن اطوار شوکتلو افندیمز حضرتلرینك متصف اولدقلری رعیت پرورلك
Translit: Şehriyâr-ı meḥâsin-i eṭvâr şevketlü efendimiz ḥażretleriniñ muttaṣıf olduḳları re'âyet-perverlik
Literal: The sovereign of beautiful manners, our majestic master His Majesty's, the subject-cherishing [quality] with which they are characterized
Modern: His Majesty our Sovereign of fine conduct is characterized by his care for his subjects.

Line 7
Script: اقتضا سنجه اخبار وفن جغرافیا واسطه سیله هر نقدر معلوم همایونلری ایسه ده
Translit: iḳtiżâsınca aḫbâr ü fenn-i coġrafya vâsıṭasıyla her ne ḳadar ma'lûm-ı hümâyûnları ise de
Literal: According to its requirement, through news and the science of geography, however much it may be their imperial knowledge, yet
Modern: Although news and the science of geography have informed His Imperial Majesty to some extent,

Line 8
Script: لیس الخبر کالمعانیه یولندن كرك اهل اسلام وكرك اهل ذمت رعایاسنك
Translit: "leyse'l-ḫaber ke'l-mu'âyene" yolundan gerek ehl-i İslâm ve gerek ehl-i żimmet re'âyâsınıñ
Literal: From the path of "the report is not like direct observation," both the Muslim subjects' and the dhimmi subjects'
Modern: Following the principle that "hearing is not like seeing," both the Muslim and non-Muslim subjects'

Line 9
Script: احوالنی وقلاع خاقانیه سنك استحکامات وکیفیاتی کمال شفقت وهمت
Translit: aḥvâlını ve ḳılâ'-ı ḫâḳâniyesiniñ istiḥkâmât ü keyfiyâtını kemâl-i şefḳat ü himmet-i
Literal: Their conditions and the imperial fortresses' fortifications and states, with complete compassion and endeavor
Modern: [To observe] their conditions, and the fortifications and state of the imperial fortresses, with complete compassion and the endeavor

Line 10
Script: علیه لرندن رأی العین مشاهده یه مقدمۀ خیر اولمق اوزره مثلی مسبوق اولمیان
Translit: 'aliyyelerinden re'ye'l-'ayn müşâhedeye muḳaddime-i ḫayr olmaḳ üzere mis̱li mesbûḳ olmayan
Literal: From their exalted [person], to observe with their own eyes, as an auspicious prelude, unprecedented in example
Modern: Of His exalted person to observe with his own eyes—as an auspicious beginning, in an unprecedented manner—

Line 11
Script: تواضعات بنده پرورانه ایله نفس نفیس همایونلرینه حرکت کلفتنی اختیار ومحضا
Translit: tevâżu'ât-ı bende-perverâne ile nefs-i nefîs-i hümâyûnlarına ḥareket külfetini iḫtiyâr ü maḥżâ
Literal: With servant-nurturing humilities, to their precious imperial person the burden of movement choosing, and purely
Modern: With humble, servant-nurturing condescension, [His Majesty] chose to burden his precious imperial person with travel, and purely

Line 12
Script: فقرایه شهریار مشفق اولدقلرینی ذاتا دخی اعلان واظهار ضمننده ذکر اولنان
Translit: fuḳarâya şehriyâr-ı müşfiḳ olduḳlarını żâten daḫi i'lân ü iẓhâr żımnında żikr olunan
Literal: That they are a compassionate sovereign to the poor, also inherently announcing and displaying, in the context of the mentioned
Modern: To announce and demonstrate his inherent compassion as a sovereign to the poor, [he visited] the mentioned

Line 13
Script: محللری معاینه یه قصد واراده بیوروب در سعادتلرندن بیك ایکیوز قرق التی
Translit: maḥalleri mu'âyeneye ḳaṣd ü irâde buyurub Der-sa'âdetlerinden biñ ikiyüz ḳırḳ altı
Literal: Places, to inspect, intending and willing, from their Gate of Felicity [Istanbul], one thousand two hundred forty-six
Modern: Places, intending to inspect [them]. [Departing] from Istanbul in [the year] one thousand two hundred and forty-six [1246 AH],

Line 14
Script: سنه سی ذی الحجة الشریفه سنك یکرمی ایکنجی ومایسك كذلك یکرمی ایکنجیسی
Translit: senesi Żi'l-ḥicce'ş-şerîfesiniñ yigirmi ikinci ve Mâyısıñ keżâlik yigirmi ikincisi
Literal: Year's, of the noble Dhu'l-Hijja, the twenty-second, and of May likewise the twenty-second
Modern: On the twenty-second of the noble month of Dhu'l-Hijja [1246], which was likewise the twenty-second of May [1831],

Script: کونی واقع اولان جمعه کونی نمازی ادادن صکره رسمی اماده اولان دوننمای
Translit: günü vâḳi' olan cum'a günü namazı edâdan ṣoñra resmî âmâde olan donanmâ-yı
Literal: On the day occurring, the Friday day, after performing the prayer, the officially prepared fleet
Modern: On the Friday that fell [on that day], after performing the Friday prayer, with the officially prepared

Script: همایون ایله شرفرسان نام فرقتینه راکبا اقدکز بوغازینه عزیمت بیوردیلر
Translit: hümâyûn ile Şeref-resân nâm firḳatîne râkiben Aḳdeñiz boġazına 'azîmet buyurdılar
Literal: Imperial, with, boarding the frigate named Şeref-resan, to the Aegean strait they deigned to depart
Modern: Imperial Fleet, [His Majesty] boarded the frigate named Şeref-resan [Honor-Bestowing] and departed for the Dardanelles.

Line 17
Script: دوننمای همایون اوچ قپاق ودرت فرقتین ودرت قوروت و بر واپور

Literal: The imperial fleet: three ships-of-the-line and four frigates and four corvettes and one steamship
Modern: The Imperial Fleet [consisted of] three ships-of-the-line, four frigates, four corvettes, and one steamship,

Literal: And two cutters, which in total are fifteen pieces of ships; six days in Gallipoli staying
Modern: And two cutters—totaling fifteen vessels. [His Majesty] stayed six days in Gallipoli,

Literal: And the Friday prayer, with the second imam who is in the royal retinue, of His Majesty the Sovereign, senior
Modern: And [performed] the Friday prayer, [led by] the Second Imam of His Majesty's royal retinue, [one of] the senior

Translit: hümâyûnı boġazda tevḳîf birle vâpûr ile işbu ḳırḳ yedi senesi Muḥarremü'l-ḥarâmıñ

Literal: Sixth, Friday day, again the prayer after performing, to the city of Gallipoli, return was commanded
Modern: Sixth, a Friday, after again performing the prayer, [His Majesty] returned to the city of Gallipoli.

Modern: On the seventh of the mentioned month, [His Majesty] departed from the mentioned city at dawn, [proceeding] to Oreşe,

Literal: And Keşan and at Cisr-i Ergene, at the notables' mansions designated as palace, and to Edirne
Modern: Keşan, and Cisr-i Ergene, [staying] at the notables' mansions designated for [his] lodging, and toward Edirne.

Literal: At three hours' distance being, at the farm named Kara Kasım, one night lodging
Modern: At the farm named Kara Kasım, which is three hours' distance [from Edirne], [His Majesty] spent one night,

Modern: And on the eleventh [of Muharram], a Wednesday, at a place half an hour from Edirne,

Summary Translation

**Internal Affairs**

The following matter concerns His Majesty our Padishah, Protector of Islam, possessed of majesty, power, and grandeur. With his benevolent intention of caring for his subjects, this is the special article describing the imperial journey to the Dardanelles and Edirne that took place several months ago, with which this newspaper has been auspiciously inaugurated.

His Majesty our Sovereign of fine conduct is characterized by his care for his subjects. Although news and the science of geography have informed His Imperial Majesty to some extent, following the principle that "hearing is not like seeing," [His Majesty resolved] to observe with his own eyes—both the Muslim and non-Muslim subjects' conditions, and the fortifications and state of the imperial fortresses—with complete compassion. As an auspicious and unprecedented beginning, with humble condescension, His Majesty chose to burden his precious imperial person with travel, and to announce and demonstrate his inherent compassion as a sovereign to the poor.

Departing from Istanbul on the twenty-second of the noble month of Dhu'l-Hijja 1246 [May 22, 1831], which fell on a Friday, after performing the Friday prayer, His Majesty boarded the frigate named Şeref-resan [Honor-Bestowing] and departed for the Dardanelles with the Imperial Fleet. The fleet consisted of three ships-of-the-line, four frigates, four corvettes, one steamship, and two cutters—totaling fifteen vessels.

His Majesty stayed six days in Gallipoli and performed the Friday prayer at the Gazi Süleyman Pasha Mosque, led by the Second Imam of his royal retinue, Mustafa Nuri Efendi, one of the senior professors. After the prayer, he departed with the fleet for Kale-i Sultaniye [Çanakkale]. After one week, leaving the Imperial Fleet at the strait, His Majesty traveled by steamship [back toward Edirne].

On the sixth of Muharram [1247], a Friday, after again performing the prayer, His Majesty returned to Gallipoli. On the seventh of the month, departing at dawn, he proceeded overland to Oreşe, Keşan, and Cisr-i Ergene, staying at the notables' mansions designated for his lodging. At the farm named Kara Kasım, three hours from Edirne, His Majesty spent one night.

On the eleventh [of Muharram], a Wednesday, His Majesty arrived at a place half an hour from Edirne. From the Solak Fountain, with a grand procession arranged in his honor, he proceeded toward the Selimiye Mosque. In its vicinity, at the mansion of the Grand Vizier's sword-bearer Raşid Ağa—which is new and pleasant and was designated as the imperial palace—His Majesty deigned to honor [with his presence].

From the mentioned fountain, the Molla of Edirne and all the ulema and sheikhs prepared for the imperial reception. The schoolteachers with all their pupils, and the Greek, Armenian, and Jewish priests and rabbis with their children, wearing their ceremonial garments, stood along the royal road, raising their voices in prayer and praise. All the people lined up along the roads with complete joy, and by observing the imperial countenance, they were gratified.

From Gallipoli to the protected city of Edirne, the deputies, notables, and leading figures of the lands that His Majesty inspected came from places half an hour away, gratefully and thankfully welcoming the royal arrival. Each official was honored by being clothed in ferâce and kukuleta robes of honor. In each place, however many poor Muslims and non-Muslim subjects there were, they were registered and abundant alms were given on their behalf—they being recipients of the most complete imperial favor.

Besides this, the food expenses of the mansions where the servants of the imperial household lodged were registered, and amounts exceeding their expenses were given [to the mansion owners]. Previously, what was called the "dörice house"...

Summary Translation

**[Continuation from RH Column]**

...Previously, what was called the "dörice house" [would] provide provisions to all the inhabitants of the locality at the price given in times of abundance, so that they would fulfill this duty. Similarly, substantial amounts required were given to the inhabitants and subjects of the districts within the Çirmen Sanjak. [His Majesty] commanded [this], and they became recipients of [the people's] prayers.

In Gallipoli, however many mosques, fountains, and schools there were, their repair was ordered, along with the water channels whose conduits had been broken for a long time. Blessed sites were visited, especially in Bolayır, where Gazi Süleyman Pasha's tomb was visited, and alms were given to its tomb-keepers and to the poor.

The notables of Gallipoli wished to arrange a grand banquet at their own expense for the imperial retinue in Bolayır, but with the consideration that it might burden the common subjects, [His Majesty] ordered its abandonment. In this way, it was shown that the comfort of the poor was paramount in His Imperial consideration.

[His Majesty inspected] the Sultaniye Fortress, Kilid-ül-Bahr [Key of the Sea], Kum Kale [Sand Fortress], Sedd-ül-Bahr [Barrier of the Sea] fortresses, Nara Point, and in those environs—including the imperial bastions [built previously by His Majesty]—and the fortifications of Bozcaada's fortress. At Kilid-ül-Bahr Fortress, [His Majesty] ordered the firing of the large cannons—each firing four-kantar shots with thirty-six okka of gunpowder. The artillery chief and soldiers, although they aimed at the notch [target], due to the awe of the exalted assembly [the Sultan's presence], proper attention was not paid. On the sea's surface, in the first attempt, it was observed by His Majesty that the shots did not ricochet as expected. With imperial instruction regarding the aiming, when fired again, the shots ricocheted nine times more and penetrated about five arşun [approximately 3.5 meters] into the ground, devastating it.

All the fortress officers, imams, and servants received robes of honor and gifts, being gratified. The poor subjects also attained abundant alms.

[His Majesty] resided in the protected city of Edirne for ten days. During this period, the first Friday [prayer was performed] at Sultan Selim Khan II's [Selimiye Mosque], and the second Friday at the Üç Şerefeli [Three-Balconied Mosque], going with a procession and performing the prayers following the Second Imam Efendi. Some blessed sites were visited, and gifts were graciously bestowed upon the poor and dervishes.

For the investigation of conditions, [His Majesty visited] twice the Çirmen Governor Hüseyin Pasha's gardens situated at the confluence of the Maritsa and Tunca rivers, and once Tağdeviran-zade Kadri Bey's garden on the Tunca riverbank.

The day after entering Edirne, [His Majesty] honored the Mansure [Victorious] Soldiers' barracks—which is among his imperial works—viewing its four sides place by place, and entering its noble mosque. The edifice's style and solidity were approved. The soldiers present stood battalion by battalion, and passing through their midst, [His Majesty gained] personal awareness of each one's clothing, conditions, and states—with imperial endeavor making their officers recipients of favor and grace. That their supplies always be prepared was His Imperial desire, [this being conveyed] to Governor-General Ahmed Pasha, commander of the Special Division who came with the imperial retinue. There, openly, [His Majesty] ordered, showing kindness to the soldiers.

[His Majesty] also personally gained information about the hospital's conditions, ordering matters to ensure the continuation of order. The settlement of matters was entrusted to Ahmed Pasha and to the deputy chief physician—one of the former officials of Mecca the Honored, the Special Physician Abdülhak Efendi—with emphasis on healing and compassion. And [His Majesty] also ordered the hospital's repair and renewal.

On the Maritsa River, the great bridge that had collapsed from the flood current previously—its renewal was ordered. The people, coming and going by boats, were saved from the hardship they endured, and became devoted to praying for the continuation of His Majesty's state.

Each one of the servants who were felicitous with the honor of the imperial retinue, departing from the protected city of Edirne during the imperial movement, attained their share of gifts and joyfully offered prayers of beneficence for His Majesty. The exalted visit to the protected city of Edirne is hereby remembered and commemorated...
